entry.title: Genius
entry.content:
This new product from Buzzi & Buzzi, owes its name to the wonderful tale of Aladdin. Genius is the latest innovation from this firm based in Canonica d’Adda and celebrating its 25th anniversary this year. The name was chosen because this amazing product satisfies the top three wishes of the technical lighting designer.

Firstly, there’s the light intensity: quite incredible for an aperture measuring only 20 mm, and able to supply a light flow of around 1000 lumen.

Secondly, there’s the look: recessed into the ceiling and without any visible fixtures, so not breaking up the surface in any way. Genius is such a tiny globe that it’s nearly invisible when switched off, but can also make objects stand out almost theatrically; shrinking the beam of light until it all but disappears. The light source produces a clear cone of light, which bathes the surface below it, evoking all the magic of a stage.

The third wish satisfied by Genius isthat of reliability: the miracle of this system is not solely confined to its ability to produce what we might term an optical illusion. Buzzi & Buzzi’s new product is in fact the only one on the market which enables you to maintain the LED system through an aperture measuring only 20 mm, thanks to a push-operated locking mechanism which allows you to extract the LED circuit and replace it immediately. The fact that Genius is fully open to inspection and that all its wearable parts can be accessed without tampering with the ceiling avoids any need for remote inspection hatches; enabling you to work on the unit very easily despite the limitations of just 2 cm of space. Genius is a concealed, recessed lighting system designed to be installed into plasterboard or brick ceilings.

The product is made from natural white AirCoral® and can be customised by the client by applying any type of paint, adapting it to the tastes and requirements of the designer.

Genius was originally published by L4A on Lighting for Architecture.

entry.title: Athens 2004 historical archive
entry.content:
The Historical Archive of the Organising Committee of the ATHENS 2004 Olympic Games covers the period from Athens’ bid for the Games to the end of Games themselves.

The Archive is located at the premises of the International Olympic Academy in Ancient Olympia in facilities covering 420 m2, and includes a rich body of printed, audiovisual and digitised material as well as official objects from the Athens Olympic Games.

The project to set up the ATHENS 2004 Historical Archive was entirely financed by a donation from the International Olympic Committee (IOC) to whom the relevant archival material belongs. Work was carried out by the non-profit organisation “ATHENS 2004 Historical Archive” which was set up specifically for this purpose.

  • Architects: F. & K. Kydoniatis Architects & Partners
  • Construction: Electron Line S.A.

entry.title: One Athens
entry.content:
In the late 1950s, Konstantinos Doxiadis, one of the leading figures of modern Greek architecture, was looking for a site to build his new company’s Athens offices. He selected a plot in the pine-clad foothills of Mount Lycabettus, a vantage point that afforded sweeping views of the city as far as the sea.

Divercity architects were inspired by Doxiadis’ philosophy when converting his former headquarters into a 21st century residential complex by the name of One Athens. Maintaining the elegant simplicity of the structure, the new design remains faithful to the legacy of this landmark, but forward-looking in its cutting-edge design, innovative use of materials, and ability to respond to modern lifestyle.

L4A continued and completed the lighting development started by Diathlasis SA.

entry.title: Nikos Koulis Athens
entry.content:
“The first Nikos Koulis Jewels Boutique in Athens, located in a posh shopping area in the city centre, is a product of a constant, evolving intercourse between masculine and feminine elements. The sources of inspiration behind its creation are universal: references to a G. Gershwin melody, a phrase by F. Scott Fitzgerald, the decolourised photography of classic films, as well as the electric vibe of New York, Paris and Shanghai, during the 1930s and 1940s.

The result is an atmospheric space resembling a woman’s boudoir, combined with the mystery of an austere men’s lounge. The eternal play of men’s attraction to women is reflected in all facets of the design: fine grey flannel on the walls, grey, black and dark green marble, intense metals such as bronze and black iron, display cases made of cement co-existing with Art Deco curved mirrors, graceful custom-made sconces, velvet and rattan textures. The space as a whole gives you a feeling of privacy and proximity, redefining the client’s stance towards the objects of desire - Nikos Koulis’ fine jewellery.

Designed by the Athens-based Stage Design Office, Stavros Papagiannis & Giorgos Kyriazis, in close collaboration with the brand owners, Nikos Koulis Jewels Boutique goes far beyond a normal commercial store, inviting its clients to experience the intimacy of an unrestrained, private moment.

Alexandros Papadias designed the marble sconces, the tailor-made vitrine étalage, as well as the bronze door knobs. Michalis Anastasiadis designed the satin brass lights, while Cypriot artist Socrates Socratous created an in-situ installation in the outdoor display area. Classic music can be heard from the outdoor loudspeakers, creating a special mood for visitors and reflecting Nikos Koulis’ special philosophy.”

  • Customer: Nikos Koulis
  • Interior Design: Stage Design Office
  • Tailor-made objects: Alexander Papadias
  • Photos: Grey Studio, Panagiotis Baxevanis

entry.title: The Greek Pavilion at the 14th Biennale
entry.content:
The Greek participation in the 14th International Architecture Exhibition - La Biennale di Venezia, entitled Tourism Landscapes: Remaking Greece was directed and curated by Greece’s National Commissioner for the Biennale, Architect and Professor Giannis Aisopos.

It explores the role of tourism as a vehicle for modernising Greece through the emergence of constructed tourism landscapes: hotels and resorts, organised beaches, archaeological sites and museums, public space designs and infrastructure facilities. Moreover, it focuses on the concurrent (re)shaping of Greek national identity, enhanced through contact with the other, with foreign, new and global elements, which tourism – as an activity – presupposes.

  • Customer: Ministry of the Environment, Energy & Climate Change
  • Commissioner - Curator: Yannis Aesopos
  • Advisors: Elias Zenghelis, Georgios Panetsos, Lois Papadopoulos
  • Assistants: Maria Chassioti, Ioanna Koulouri, Georgios Kourakos, Mina Roussou, Thodoris Svoronos

entry.title: Nikos Koulis, Mykonos
entry.content:
The inspiration behind the design for the first Nikos Koulis Jewels Boutique on Mykonos was the brand’s very own logo. Designed by Stage Design Office, Stavros Papagiannis and Giorgos Kyriazis, along with the brand owners, this new boutique has caused an international sensation. The austere and emblematic logo invokes religious symbolism and required the adoption of an ascetic aesthetic that makes multiple references to the Cycladic tradition.

The large stone floor slabs originating from the nearby island of Rineia, the vintage wooden door and the arches in the stone walls were preserved and combined with the ethereal cast-iron displays and the white marble surfaces, which allow daylight to diffuse into this once dark cellar space, thereby intensifying the emotional aspect as visitors discover and uncover the jewels inside. The marble counter reminds one of an altar where the jewels are showcased in sacramental fashion, while the tailor-made pews from the same material, redefine the client’s stance towards the object of desire, establishing respect and proximity.

The boutique’s exterior follows the same intrinsic approach, with a discreet logo and a small suspended display, reflecting Nikos Koulis’ special philosophy.

  • Customer: Nikos Koulis
  • Interior Design: Stage Design Office
  • Special Marble Items: Alexander Papadias
  • Electrician: Dimitris Protopapadakis
  • Photos: Grey Studio, Panagiotis Baxevanis

All images courtesy of Stage Design Office. Used under permission.
